Award.AwardTitle: Sparsity-promoting optimal design of large-scale networks of dynamical systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Sparsity-promoting optimal design of large-scale networks of dynamical systems

The proposal introduces new methods for the design of large-scale networks of dynamical systems. Systems of this type arise in applications ranging from distributed power generation, to coordination of unmanned aerial vehicles and deployment of teams of robotic agents, to control of fluid flows around wind turbines and vehicles, to control of segmented mirrors in extremely large telescopes. One of the major challenges in systems with large number of degrees of freedom is the development of analytical and computational methods for their tractable analysis and design.

Interactions between subsystems often induce complex dynamical responses that cannot be predicted by analyzing subsystems in isolation. Blackouts in power networks, congestion in transportation networks, spatio-temporal oscillations in biochemical networks, turbulence in fluid flows, and the spread of information in social networks illustrate the complex and seemingly unpredictable behavior that arises in systems of high dynamical order. The broader impacts of the proposed work range from improved performance and suppression of blackouts in power systems to systematic design of sensor networks and multi-agent systems. The educational aspect of the proposal is to develop a new introductory course on analysis and design of networks. This course will be aimed at attracting students from diverse engineering departments at senior undergraduate and first year graduate levels.

The intellectual merit lies in the development of theory and techniques for structure identification and optimal design of large networks of dynamical systems. The PI will combine tools and ideas from control theory, optimization, and compressive sensing to achieve an optimal tradeoff between network performance and controller sparsity. The proposed approach involves both structure identification and structured optimal design steps. In the structure identification step, sparsity will be induced by regularizing an optimal control problem with a penalty on communication requirements in the distributed controller. In contrast to previous efforts, this penalty will reflect the fact that sparsity should be enforced in a specific set of coordinates. After having identified a controller structure, the structured optimal design step will optimize the network performance over the identified structure. Alongside the sparse feedback synthesis, the PI will address the critical question of optimal sensor and actuator selection in large-scale networks.

Although, in general, finding the solution to this problem requires an intractable combinatorial search, this award will draw upon recent developments in sparse representations to cast it as a semidefinite program (SDP). While the resulting SDP can be solved using general-purpose solvers, the PI will develop customized algorithms to exploit the problem structure and reduce computational complexity. Such customized solvers will be capable of dealing with large problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this NSF Award is in the development of theory and techniques for topology design and optimal synthesis of large-scale networks of dynamical systems. Such systems are encountered in numerous applications including networks of autonomous robots, intelligent buildings, flexible wing aircraft, extremely large telescopes, and frequency synchronization in the power grid. They typically involve independent agents which have limited information exchange over a network. Relative to centralized systems in which an all-to-all communication architecture can be afforded, limited information exchange between agents introduces numerous challenges for analysis, optimization, and control design. The PI combined tools and ideas from control theory, optimization, and compressive sensing to strike an optimal balance between network performance and controller sparsity. The proposed approach consists of two steps: (i) topology design; and (ii) optimal synthesis in the presence of pre-specified structural constraints. In the topology design step, sparsity is induced by regularizing an optimal control problem with a penalty on communication requirements in the distributed controller. After having designed a controller structure, the structured optimal synthesis step optimizes the network performance over the identified structure.

The broader impacts range from improved performance of power systems to systematic design of multi-agent systems. For example, in power systems, complex dynamics of power transfers may induce oscillations between different groups of generators. Current pace of adding new transmission facilities does not provide an adequate means for dealing with increased deployment of renewable energy sources, deregulation of energy markets, and steady growth in long-distance power transfer demand. All of these may contribute to a heavily stressed grid in which poorly damped inter-area modes can become unstable, thereby resulting in blackouts and significant threats to economy and security. A distributed wide-area control, in which local control actions are formed using remote measurements, has been suggested as a promising strategy for dealing with these challenges. Recent advances in communication networks, flexible AC transmission systems, and high-bandwidth phasor measurement units make such approach technologically feasible but the question of how to design controllers that use limited information exchange between geographically distant generators has remained open. The PI combined these technological developments with theory and techniques developed in this NSF Award in order to strike an effective balance between performance of power systems and sparsity of the controller. Optimal distributed wide-area controllers, which require modest communication and computation overhead and make use of readily accessible angle and frequency measurements, were designed and feasibility of this approach was demonstrated in IEEE benchmark problems. The proposed design preserves rotational symmetry of the power network by allowing only relative angle measurements and furnishes optimal distributed controllers that can effectively guard against local and inter-area oscillations.
